channel.description: Recent content in javascript on Martin Trojer

item.title: Embedding a new runtime into your legacy C/C++ app
item.description: Let’s say you have a big / legacy C++ app, then you’re undoubtedly covered by Greenspun’s tenth rule. Let’s also say that your home-grown, buggy and slow DSL / scripting language has been pushed to the limit and can not be tweaked any further. What do you do, how can you replace it? As you might expect, this is quite a common problem, and embedding scripting languages into a big C/C++ monolith is popular.

item.title: Some thoughts on Clojure performance
item.description: Edit: This post recently re-surfaced on hacker news and caused a bit of a stir, mainly because of a slightly sensational/misleading title (was “Why is Clojure so slow?”). I wrote this before Rich Hickey’s Clojure/Conj 2011 keynote was published, in which he talks about most of my concerns (and outlines possible solutions). Clojure is great in many ways, but one thing it can’t be accused of is being particularly fast. What I mean by fast here is the speed in which Clojure programs execute.
